So MEH. Deck builder / combat / race for points game with Dune theming. Massively overhyped, I can't believe it's rating. A sub-par worker placement mechanic plus a bad deck builder and swingy combat dominated by hideously random intrigue cards. And >3 hours to play. Flush the tanks! I'd play Risk over this nonsense. This is not a Top100 boardgame by any stretch.
+ Understated board art
- Random market flop
- Combat is by far the best way to get VPs, the spot that delivers additional troops for combat is too important (Heighliner?)
- Pointlessness of solari at end game
- Few options to actually deck build
x Ridiculously swingy intrigue cards
x Caused AP in my group so games run >3 hours. The decision tree isn't rich enough to justify a 3 hour game and there is so much randomness built in. I was so bored during this game.

The deckbuilding is dull, the resource conversion is dull, the worker placement is worker placement, the bidding-battles could be more exciting. It's just a mishmash of stuff. Well at least the scores usually stop around a dozen points.

I played this game well over 20 times in total. I played both offline and online and I feel this game is best played online on steam. However the game has a lot of problems and I don't think the expansions solve these problems.

1) One of my online games I was able to win by drawing the exact three intrigue cards I needed to win in the last round. At that point I don't really feel like I won, but I just ended up getting lucky. To me this is a huge problem with the game.

2) You can get lucky by having the right amount of buying power when a really strong card becomes available or you can get unlucky, by having the opposite happening to you and some of these cards are able to turn the game up side down on their own. While it is true that you don't need good cards to win the game, you do need some decent cards in addition to your starting cards to be able to compete properly and if nothing good becomes available to you, then you are most likely going to be screwed.

3) Player skill does matter. If you have even one bad player on your table, then that may result in a runaway leader on its own. Dune Imperium is at its best when each player knows what to do and when to do it. This means that if a single player is oblivious about the right course of actions, then they won't counter somebody when they could have or should have.

So to summarize. There is to much luck involved in the intrigue cards, the cards you can buy (which ones show up and when they show up) and the tech (expansion, which ones show up and when they show up). There is also no clear solution for any of these problems either. If you get dealed a bad hand, you can still perform decently well, but your odds at actually winning decrease by a lot. On the opposite end if you get dealed a good hand, your odds at winning increases and while you still have to properly play the game, the game already worked in your favor. To me Dune Imperium is a game that frustrated the hell out of me. I like the idea of it, but I dislike the randomness of it and given how much time we have to spend upon this world, I rather spend my time elsewhere.

Very run of the mill worker placement game, with more rules and less strategy. Outcome heavily guard-railed and based on turn order. Theme does not come through at all.

Ah, Dune Imperium. Oh, I really wanted to like this game. I enjoy the Dune IP so I had to really work hard to separate my bias since of course, based on the theme alone, I would want to like it. Initially, I did like it. However, I couldn't ignore it's glaring flaws.

Dune Imperium is another one of those modern day games where every action is rewarded and leads to the same outcome, regardless of what you do. Hence, "the illusion of choice" as I like to put it. As every action is rewarded, nothing you do really matters. Hence, the game is designed to rubber band players for a close finish where the end game devolves to luck with best drawn intrigue cards.

-Have troops available? Try your hand at the conflict and gain an influence point.
-Have a surplus of persuasion points? Just pass early and buy a,"Spice May Flow," card to collect an influence point.
-Have diplomacy cards? Boost yourself on the alliance track and get a point.

The illusion of choice here creates a disguised, bland strategic experience.

The luck element of the game is poorly implemented through the use of the intrigue deck. I have no issue with luck implemented in games if it can allow a player to employ a clever strategy as a result. However, this game dumbs it down to, "Let's pull the lever on the slot machine of the intrigue deck and see if I hit that 777." Simply milling an intrigue deck for game breaking cards does not equate to strategic play that's fulfilling as a player. As a result, this game can be rather swingy, unjustly.

Additionally, the mid through end game strategy devolved down to be the same for all players: Let's hoard 6 spice and see who can be the first person to place their agent on the heighliner board space to deploy 7 troops EVERY SINGLE TIME. You'd be a fool not to place an agent on this spot for the Space Guild. Compare this board space to the Emperor's conspire board space, and it really pales in comparison. The Emperor's conspire space allows a player to spend 4 spice and acquire 5 wealth, 2 troops (which you can't deploy), and an intrigue card. Thematically, the Emperor has access to Sardaukar terror troops and you mean to tell me that's the best he can do? The Heighliner spot is clearly the best space in the game where players would want to ensure they can go as often as possible.

Let's face it, the graphic design on the board was lazy, and a completely missed opportunity.

The game is light on player interaction. The combat is uninteresting. You could slap any theme on these game mechanisms. When it comes to the Dune theme, I'll stick to the Avalon Hill classic. Further, when it comes to deck building + worker placement/area control, I'll take "A Study in Emerald" or Legends of the hidden Arnak any day over this.

Originally rated a 4 after testing the game, but I dropped my rating to 2.5 after the designer became butthurt over my original rating and sent me a private message about my rating. He complained that either I should explain why I dislike the game (which, had he bothered to read my playtesting review, he would have known why) or remove my rating (which I most certainly won't). I've played over 5,000 games in my life. I don't have the time or wherewithal to make comments on all 5,000+ games, and I certainly will not give special treatment to this game simply because the designer whined about one rating. Game recuperated a half-point in November 2021. After much soul searching, I dropped my rating back to 2.4 in May 2025 as I am unable to overlook Dennen's attitude toward me personally.

Played this a few more times recently, and wow, it’s just really an awful game. WTF people? See djberg96’s comment for a deeper dive into why this games suck so hard beyond my comments below.
—-
This is another one of those games (like Terraforming Mars, Terra Mystica, Nevsky, COIN) that I played so much and went so far out of my way to try to like, just because they are so popular, that I ended up despising it more than is possibly reasonable. I rate it a 2, because it is in fact quite bad - if I had to play this regularly then I’d probably rather just leave the hobby. But maybe for most normal people it’s a 4 or 5 bad, not a 2 bad.
—-
Here are the house rules I play with: remove all cost-1 cards from the Imperium deck, and make the market row 6 cards instead of 5. At the end of each turn, trash and replace the oldest card in the market. This actually helps a *lot*. Unfortunately it unmasks a bunch of other problems with the game which are not so easily fixable, so I’m not raising my rating. But it makes it a lot more playable.
—-
A bit of face-to-face play in between various spikes has really tanked the rating on this. The balance is just quite bad. The Imperium Deck is full of worthless cards and it's very easy for the Imperium Row to get gummed up with garbage nobody wants to buy, which just kills the game. The Intrigue deck is amazingly uneven. And the real problem is that you just don't cycle your deck that much, maybe 4-5 times in a game, maybe even less. This turns too many low-priced cards into worse-than-useless garbage.

Also: the weird way it covers only the material from the first movie (half the book) leaves it just feeling really thin. The Dune flavor is extremely limited to begin with, but leaving out half the book and family atomics, Feyd Rautha, Alia, etc., it just doesn't feel like there is a lot there. Then for the first expansion they go to the execrable prequels rather than doing something from core Dune.

Really surprised how much love this game has gotten given how obviously problematic so many elements are. I like Clank! well enough but I don't need to play this again. I hope that Dune: A Game of Conquest & Diplomacy will deliver something better.
---
This has settled in to get some semi-regular play. The hype on this one seems a little nuts, with an 8.5 average rating. It’s a perfectly workmanlike piece of design work - but not really that remarkable. The length, especially with 4, is just a big problem.
---
The availability of better TTS modules recently has helped here. I really wish the graphic and physical design of this was more interesting. It’s not terrible, it’s just not that evocative - I’m not sure if this is just because it was tightly bound to a movie that nobody is going to see for quite a while still? But it’s just surprisingly bland.

So anyway, my opinion of this has been trending up a bit, but not to the tune of another rating point.

I’m also pretty convinced for now that this really wants 4 players. The balancing for fewer does not seem particularly convincing, and the dynamics of the conflict cards seems not ideal at 3.

Still also really needed to trim about 20% from the play time.
—-
I should also say I’m super-concerned about the playing time. I haven’t had a game come in under 2 hours, and a 4-player game that went the distance hasn’t come in at under 3. This needs to be 90m, 2h tops.
—
Played twice, enjoyed. But it doesn’t feel like it’s quite good enough to get repeat play. The unevenness in the Intrigue cards and Factions in particular does not seem great - it’s a huge competitive boon to get a couple good Intrigue cards early, and by the same token investing your very limited resources early and getting cards that are effectively no-ops is bad. It also appears that the game really kinda needs the full compliment of 4 players - the scaling to play with fewer players clearly is not great.

The Dune flavor is also ok but nothing to write home about. The intrigue in Dune is about intricate plots and sudden strikes, while Dune: Imperium is a classic deck building grind. While there is strenuous competition over conflict zones, which is nice, there are no high-stakes sudden reveals and limited hidden information.

So, I dunno, I was hoping it would be at minimum a serviceable eurogame. I think it’ll probably clear that bar but not go much higher.
—
So, yes, it looks like this will be a pretty traditional deck-builder which leans into the tropes of deckbuilders a lot more than the tropes of Dune. That’s fine! It’s not going to be the next coming of Avalon Hill’s Dune, but it seems like it’ll be a fun Dune-flavored thing. I pre-ordered it; it helped that I really enjoyed Clank.

This game suffers from most of the problems of modern Euros, especially the fact it's been designed around the idea of combining the fashionable elements of deck-building and worker placement as expediently as possible, without really thinking if that is the best way to serve the setting and intention of the game.

I was a bit blown away on first rules learning (via the very flashy but largely-well-done Steam app) with the number of different rules that needed to be introduced. Every time I thought "well at least I've learned the game now", a new concept and set of worker placement spaces were introduced. I find the idea that many players play this game with multiple expansions utterly incomprehensible: the base game is already creaking at the seams. It needed systems, spaces, and card types to be removed, not added, if it were truly to become a great game.

The whole game feels very affected by the issues that have plagued many a post-Dominion deck-building game: especially, the randomness of when you draw particular cards from your highly-variable starting deck and what exactly is in the limited-selection buy-row at any point in time. These factors are going to affect the outcome of your games. That's not necessarily a bad thing - I suspect that I enjoy a high-luck, high-skill game more than your average BGGer - but it does make it a surprise that this game is as highly-regarded as it is.

Whilst it's possible no game could do treatment to Dune adequately from a thematic perspective, Imperium falls short by creating something largely uninteractive and especially where most players' path through the game is to achieve friendship with every non-player faction: something which is certainly beyond all the major "players" in the Dune universe in the books/films.

"The Conflict" each turn does stand out, in that it does a good job of focusing central attention, creating something of an auction. Compared to most modern Euro games, this is far more interactive and interesting. At its best, with intrigue cards being flung to change the values in the conflict or even to pull out at the last minute and save for the next one, it feels a bit like Condottiere - except that Dune: Imperium as a whole is far less accessible, leading one to question why one wouldn't just play Condottiere instead.

After initially finding it slightly less egregious than many modern Euros and especially thinking the conflict was well-done as described above, a torturous three-hour second play which suggested "Downtime: Imperium" might be a more appropriate name persuaded me to drop this to a 2.

Sort of a dumpster fire of a game. Lots of direct attacks, and take that happening in the game. If you like randomly losing your turn because another player takes an action that totally negates your action, this may be the game for you. Awful balancing of spaces, with some basically unusable, which I guess is par for most worker placement games. Not a good game in terms of balancing or design, but at least it's basically never fun either. Board looks fine, art is decent. Decent components. We did have a couple times where players mistook player pawns for dreadnaughts. The expansion seems to make the game worse, as they do more often then not. The smuggling spaces were basically always first picked, so much so that people even prioritized the space guild to have more access to them. The variable powers are not even close to being balanced, with some just clearly better then others. The intrigue cards and techs were similarly unfun as they range mostly as either worthless or busted. Battles seemed the icing on the crap salad of a game. One battle in our game saw a single troop beat another player who had deployed nearly all of their troops. Seems bad when a 12/1 advantage can't get it done. The rewards also varied so much, there was a turn where everyone basically said they didn't even care to fight because it wasn't worth putting troops in for the reward offered, to the next turn where 2 VP were for winner only, with a relatively minor prize for 2nd. At least the game isn't 100% winner takes all, it just winner takes everything anyone cares about most of the time. In the end, this game fails in nearly every way in terms of design and play. Most of the people at the table just wanted the game to end by the end. It was a truly a beating to play this game. They really got their moneys worth from the IP on this one, as it would be a complete loser without it.

My friends and I couldn't finish a single play through. The game is ill designed in several ways:

1. Complexity for complexity's sake, but with no payoff. There are 6 in-game currencies: spice, solari, water, troops, influence, and persuasion. There are also several types of cards. Each turn takes place through 5 phases. Complexity is alright, when the complexity adds to the game, allowing for an interesting and balanced profusion of strategies. This takes me to point 2.

2. The game is linear. I've played the game once, the following seems very likely true:
The game reduces to Get Solari, Go to Swordsmaster, Get more Solari, Go to High Council, Win Battles. In that order.

There's some variation in how players get the in-game currencies, and the deck building dynamic adds a small amount of diversity to game strategies. That still fails to mitigate for the central fact of the game being simultaneously excessively complex and unfortunately linear.

Quasi ameritrash that pretends to be the eurogame. Chaos, chaos, chaos. All you do here is luck dependent. You want to place the worker on the board but you can’t because you didn’t draw the proper card. When finally you’ve got it the other player was faster and blocked that space. You want to buy a card from the market but there’s nothing interesting at this moment at the price you can afford, so you buy whatever or your money (persuasion) is gone. You’ve well prepared your troops to win the combat but suddenly someone plays the card that turns the result upside down. Forget about controlling and planning your moves.

I’m sorry but I prefer the „Clank” that has identical card driven mechanism, almost the same iconography, the same luck dependency but without all these euro-like elements and finally it doesn’t pretend to be something more than pure spontanous fun. +1 point for „Clank” resemblance.

Agonizing first play experience. I immediately sold the game and would never play again. Our game was so endless that my friend managed to play Terraforming Mars (with expansions) while we played this... and when he returned, we still had plenty of game left. We eventually just quit the game because none of us wanted to play anymore. We checked the remaining cards and the game would've definitely ended with the deck running out, which takes ages. Even if our game's length was some kind of unusual anomaly, I still hate the game. (1) It's incredibly boring. The cards are mundane 'go here'. The action spots are basically all 'get water/spice/silver'. The cards you buy are equally dull and there's no combo-chaining or any of the other stuff that makes deck-builders fun. (2) For all the talk of this being deeper than Arnak, I found the decisions actually much easier to make; it's a shallow decision space (3) Intrigue cards vary from nearly useless to incredibly powerful. Much of the game ends up being determined by a random draw. Overall: I wish I could see what others see in this game, but I just don't. It is infinitely worse than deck-builders like Clank or Quest for El Dorado, much less fun than Arnak, and certainly nowhere near as deep as most worker placements. War, the best part of this game, is far better done in Blood Rage or Inis, which I'd both highly recommend. There's just nothing here that a bunch of other games don't do better.

I bought this game because of the hype. I am very surprised it is getting this much attention. I found it tedious and boring. Someone in my group said it feels like "grinding" in a videogame, and I think that about captures the experience for me. It will not stay in my collection.

I sincerely tried to like the game. But after 3 plays with different parties I can surely tell that I don't want to try it once more. Card balance is a joke, as many other people already complained. And it's not just about "Kwisatz Haderach", which is essentially "I win" card if you get it by round 4. But even between card with the same cost their usefulness varies greatly, like that card with cost 3 that allows you to remove a card AND get 2 spice while you're at it.

This imbalance snowballs into many more other problems in the game. The biggest issue is the feelings of practically every player during the entire playthrough. I played a lot of other games with the same people, but I noticed that this particular game just makes people sad and salty most of the time instead of making them enjoy the process. It's hard to blame people for being annoyed when pure luck is a major factor and the outcome is frequently decided on whether you got any useful cards in the Imperium Row by your turn. Imagine having 6-8 persuasion with not a single useful card to buy, so you have to spend it on some utter trash only to reveal some ultimate top card for the next player. Yup, happens all the time.

Same imbalance problem with intrigue cards, there some are much more useful than others, and it's only a matter of luck to get anything good. In our second game, a guy won by drawing a single intrigue card with +9 combat strength, which he got for taking 2nd place in combat, so that let him win the next combat and get +2 VP. Imagine how 2 other players felt when they were focusing on Intrigue cards the entire game and always got some useless trash.

That being said, having any strategy is pretty much pointless, and whether you win or not is always due to luck. That's definitely not what I would expect from a strategy game, making it the second game ever in my entire collection that I seriously consider to just give to somebody else.

I was expecting a great game based on all the praise I’d read, but the disappointment was severe. It felt like a mix of mechanics thrown together, with none of them fully fleshed out. Too long, very “Euro,” yet it ends with a completely luck-of-the-draw finish. Maybe I’m missing something (I’ve only played it once, with the Rise of Ix expansion).

I've never played this game, but I did play uprising once, which is enough to know this game is godawful.

uprising review that probably applies here:
I can't remember the last time I hated a game more. Maybe root? Every moment I was either bored to tears or extremely frustrated. I wanted to scream.

Like most bad worker placements, there is absolutely no reason to pay attention when it's not your turn. Other people act with total impunity on their turns, there is no reason to predict what they might do, you cannot respond, and every thing they do cuts a firewall across your decision space. there's no reason to plan ahead. Start your thinking over on your turn.

All the tiles and cards in this game come out in the worst way. They are the dreaded "situationally good". What cards/contacts are available on your turn is basically random. Some cards are fucking phenomenal for only one player. Some cards are fucking phenomenal for anyone, but you will not be allowed to buy them, because they were drawn randomly right before your opponents purchase phase. Has there ever been a good game with a card river?

This has all of the bad things about deck building with none of the good (the good requires control over the contents and the cycling of your deck, and frequent shuffling, eg dominion). There's really zero efficient deck management actions on the action board, the trashing spots are not worth an entire worker action. In this respect, Factions are wildly imbalanced when it comes to deck management and how well they can use good cards (Factions that trash with their signet action, especially when randomly served with great cards they can afford, dominate).
Your randomly drawn hands limit your actions the same way the draw bag controls War Chest (aka chess but bad when it counts), you might just be dealt an awful round at key moments, which would be fine if the game were shorter, but one bad hand sticks with you for half an hour. Dominion works because the deck control is extremely high, the market is equally available to all players, you shuffle dozens of times, and the game is over in fifteen minutes. This is a shambling 3 hour monstrosity.

The point scoring system is as bad as they come. Like most limp modern euros, the game artificially creates a close end-game point spread then has a wild final turn. The majority of the points in the game (the faction bumps) are participation trophies. The remaining points have wildly differing costs. Some combats are hard fought, and others just showing up is enough, and you can't predict the mood. The intrigue cards award points basically at random. No one sees enough intrigue cards to have truly chosen a set that matches their plans, but then end game comes and people pull 3 points out of their hat like a magic trick, with cards that finish scoring half-completed objectives you couldn't possibly have counter played.

Anyone who likes modern board games can find fun in pulling levers and collecting resources on their turn, especially if they win. There are two criteria I look at with every game
1. Am I still having fun when it's not my turn? Do I care what other people are doing? Does it create new opportunities in the gamespace? do I have agency to respond? Are we negotiating? Are we even just laughing about what people chose to do? Absolutely not in this game.
2. When the game is over, does the whole table agree the player who won played the best? and then can we examine the choices they made and understand what they did well that we can emulate in a future game? No, not really.

The art direction chose to use the faces of famous actors from the vile and lifeless recent movies, which just instantly dates the game to the era. Oh, look, it's Lil Timmy Mumbles, Christopher Walken, and the jock from the goonies.

My concerns:

My opinion is an unpopular one, and perhaps derives more from the people I played this game with than the game itself.

What I most disliked about this game is the frequency at which my investments did not pay off. Like, seriously, this is the only heavy game I've ever played which if you are still learning and playing badly or against more experienced opponents, the mechanics seem to basically shut you out of making any progress at all. It's extremely frustrating.

Draw a good hand to play the conflict? Well, if someone else drew a slightly better hand and you have no use for the consolation prize you are screwed. Draw a good hand for buying cards? Well, you better hope there is something interesting in the market, otherwise you will be flushing your influence down the toilet, or you will face the classic random-market-deck-builder scenario of having to pick up shitty cards just so a good card becomes available for your opponents to buy on the next turn. Draw a good hand for faction actions? Well, you better hope you can get the resources you need to pay for them or those will go to your discard pile without you being able to make use of them and you will have to cycle through your entire deck again (which, by the way, if you're last in turn order is probably not going to work out).

At least if I sit down to, I dunno, like Brass or Gaia Project or something and I have no idea what I'm doing I can still play and try to score some points while losing badly. Not here.

If you are unlucky with the card draw on the first or second turn, you can really be shafted and there is no way to recover. Definitely shows a lack of playtesting. Far better worker placement games out there. Avoid this.

This game, to me, captures the primary issues I've seen in the last 10 years of board game design. The game creates an illusion of interaction or decisions, but in reality the game is playing itself and you're along for the ride.

I imagine the icon matching mechanic for worker placement was meant to create tough tradeoffs, but the reality is that the cards dictate what to do on your turn. It is not hard to find the most efficient action as the resource collection and conversion economy is simple (yet somehow clunky?) and it's just a matter of being able to take the most resource efficient actions based on turn order and card draw.

The "deck building" is based on a random offering of 5 cards. I get it, conveyor belts are a way to create a card market, but you are just building the deck the game gives you, not one you have built yourself. Not to mention that you really shouldn't have deck building as a mechanic without active deck cycling. In this game, you add 5 - 10 cards to your deck and hope you draw them over 10ish turns reshuffling your discard maybe 3 or 4 times. A key aspect of why deckbuilders work is because you can create synergies between cards and efficiency to have those cards on the same turn more often. This game offers little to no synergies or efficiencies. They exist, but not in a way that meaningfully impacts your turn.

I'm all for borrowing ideas from other games and improving on them, but this one didn't bring anything new to the table for me.

I've come to realize after many games that the game is wildly chaotic in a bad way. The actions I can take are determined by the symbols on the cards. I have to choose a hand with them and hope that no one will occupy these squares for me (which happens regularly in games with 4 players). Sure, I should buy cards from the market so that I have a variety of symbols. But the market can also be terribly random. At one point, card prices were so high that they were completely stagnant. The cards have such a random combination of effects and symbols that even buying them did not always make sense, and the "money" was lost (it does not go to the next round). There was only one space in the game that guaranteed cards were removed from the deck, but it was so expensive (unless someone blocked it for you) that it often didn't make sense. Intrigue cards should be dealt BEFORE the game so that there is no situation where I get a useless one or even draw one that ACCIDENTALLY wins the game. This one is a mess. It pretends to be a heavy strategy game, but in reality the level of control over anything is very low.

New review posted 2025-01-12 after playing 4-player (and after having gained some more experience in the hobby): downgraded from 6 to 4.

I was hopeful that playing with actual thinking, breathing humans would perhaps make the gaming experience more enjoyable, but I really don't get what people see in this game. It is a jack of all trades but a master of none; an unrewarding slog with many issues and I'm not confident I see a way for all of them to be fixed by the addition of house rules or even expansions. I maintain that the theme is absent and this is essentially a convoluted abstract in an ugly, devoid-of-soul package. It also takes far longer than 2 hours to play with a full table, making it a snoozefest. For that kind of time investment, there are better games you can bring to the table.

I do wonder what has driven the average BGG user to rate this game so highly. Complexity for complexity's sake? Thank you, next.

Review below from 2022-01-04 after playing several games of 2-player with the app randomly choosing 3rd player actions:

Kind of disappointed!

Pros:
- Not terribly difficult to learn

- Lots of variety

Cons:
- Deck building element is extremely light; combos seem to happen only once in a blue moon, especially in 2-player games since there's less turnover in the store
- Cards, board, and meeple are kind of ugly
- Board could have been bigger so as to accommodate e.g. the store, intrigue cards

- Bot play (when playing solo or 2p) is flat and there seems to be a lot of RNG with respect to the battles. App does literally nothing but flip through its cards. I think this aspect is the one I hate the most - that in order for this to be more than a mediocre game, you *need* 3-4 players.
- Box quality is awful - board doesn't lay flat, there are no separators for cards, and cards don't have a fitted space in the box

Overall feels like a cash grab. I just don't understand the universal acclaim for it. I may end up selling.

After a while you start to notice more issues creeping up beyond the simple fact the game is ugly as sin. This is incredibly overrated.

There's quite a few balance issues that have arisen. A lot of the cards in the deck are straight out garbage and there's no rule for the tableau display to auto-scrap cards so it clogs up with trash so fast. Some cards like Worm Riders are overpowered. There's only 2 scoring cards in the Intrigue deck that are not only easy to achieve but basically can auto-win the game for anyone lucky enough to get them. Some spaces barely get used. It's practically mandatory to get your third worker so the game is a bit on rails. Just a lot of small problems that are adding up to one big thing. It started off as an 8, it's down to a 6, might even go to a 5 eventually and it's probably a cull from the collection.

For me this game was a disappointment on several fronts (taking into account the fact that I am a follower of the literary saga). And since the recent reprint is practically the same, my opinion is applicable to it too. Of course these are my opinions.
1)The box is too big for the contents.
2) The components in just sufficient quantities. At some point in the rules it is written that if during the game they should be scarce to replace them with other material (like the dear old colored buttons of the grandmother).
3) The price could be 20% lower on both editions.
4)The setting
Not existent. Putting the names of the various subjects of Dune is not enough for anything. It could be anything even on the day of the market in the village.
5)Despite the idea of the mechanics as a whole is good, their development and dynamics that arise in the game, reveal a superficial and unprofessional playtest. How could a publishing house of this level and a good creator have produced such a poorly curated thing?
6) The race to 10 victory points and the various ways to get them, in some ways reminded me a lot of the settlers of catan. But unfortunately while they are obvious that the dice are thrown and what happens is good, here the addition of randomness of the various parts (deck building, cards intrigue, player’s turn, powers of the houses), leads to a management chaos that is often more of a pain or boredom than fun.
7) The very high rating was given by me enthusiasm for a game labeled Dune that came far away from the first (now old even if with mechanics still good). Once you get on the table, you see the problems and are disappointed in many ways.

In the end my advice is: "play but don’t buy it".

Not good on several fronts. Some highlights:

Endless wheel of resource conversions and faction tracks to unlock...more resources. Yawn. Even special abilities are barely thematic. They're just more "stuff" to internalize. The rulebook doesn't help in this regard, with a fair number of special cases that make it feel less streamlined than it could be.

Blocking-as-interaction. Yawn. Worse, you don't have time to proactively block when resources are so scarce, so the blocking is accidental, acting as randomness instead of intentional player interaction. Also, unlucky card draws and turn order will block you just as often, meaning that its scarcity (and frustration as a result of this) is baked into the design.

The game's combat isn't combat. Not really. It's just another resource to acquire and optimize. Only intrigue cards sporadically inject something unexpected. Regardless, it lacks the visceral excitement of actual combative games. Limited combat-cube slots also often means winners in crucial rounds are determined by turn order, not via tactical play. It gets compared occasionally to Arctic Scavengers for its combat phase, but that one features psychological factors like bluffing, double-bluffing and escalating brinksmanship over combat bonuses. No such possibilities exist in D:I.

I see almost zero thematic connection overall. It's borrowing an IP for sales, not making a thematic or narrative statement through gameplay.

+ mechanics (combination of deck building and worker placement, integration of conflict/combat in this kind of game, intrigue cards, faction allegiance tracks, multiple uses for cards, ...) and how they're used somewhat thematically

0 the Dune theme

- box-sized manual is awkward, insert suboptimal

Additionally the big combat bonuses make them very powerful and swingy in combat. And there are spots where the automa never goes to (research station, sietch, CHOAM, Mentat, ...). What the automa does is pretty chaotic and luck-dependent. The fact that the human player is restricted by what comes up in the Imperium Row and 2 automa players are not, does not work well.

Half of the deck consists of cheap cards which rarely get bought, because they are too weak and blow up your deck. When you don't get the right cards, you don't have any means to work around that. Since the cards allow to which worker spots you can go, this can be a problem for all the other implemented mechanisms. I like the worker placement part. I like the bidding for battle, but the underlying deckbuilding base is so underdeveloped for me, that I rather like to play much better and lighter deckbuilders like The Quest for El Dorado, which allow you to actually build your deck strategically.

+Base Game [4.0] It's not to everyone's taste, but I like the combo-mechanic this shares with LOST RUINS OF ARNAK, i.e., part-worker placement, part minimalist "deck builder". Deck builder in scare quotes because you DO purchase better cards to improve subsequent draws, but it's a much leaner implementation of traditional deck building, and far from the only focus of the game (cf. something like DOMINION). It creates a strict and tight gaming experience with very little fat; every decision is critical and involves its own miniature optimization puzzle. I enjoy the combat system here, too - extremely simple to understand and execute, and the mitigation tactics and uncertainties (the Mentat, intrigue cards, etc.) create good tension.

+Dune: Imperium — Rise of Ix [5.0] The base game is great, but this expansion is a "must have" for me at this point. It leaves most of the core mechanics alone while improving one major flaw: The sharp depreciation of Soleri during mid/endgame, implementing a brilliant "shipping track" system that also makes the base game's weakest faction much more attractive. I prefer the Dreadnaughts here over the "worms" used in the new UPRISING game(s).

+Dune: Imperium — Immortality [3.0] The RISE OF IX expansion fixed what I’d consider a flaw in the base game. IMMORTALITY, on the other hand, doesn’t “fix” anything, because there was nothing left to fix. It merely adds additional chrome that, while occasionally fun, wasn’t needed and thus feels ancillary. Did this game really need a tech tree?

After having played at least 200 games, with various combinations of expansions, I can confidently say D:I is very good, but not perfect.

Deckbuilding is fun, but ultimately, you'll realize the game becomes a race to buy 'the good cards' from the market, after which it stagnates. Even with Immortality and the nuke token, it still feels like it's mostly just RNG who gets the right deck order to buy 'the good cards'.

And 'the good cards' can be quite swingy. Some cards, like Liet Kynes, can break the game. But even more important, access to factions is crucial to get in this game. For those who don't know, it typically takes 8 actions to earn 4 points from faction tracks, maybe 6-7 with other boosts. You should also cycle your deck every 2 rounds. That means it's necessary to buy at least 1 faction access card to maintain point tempo.

This leads to the single biggest weakness of the card market, which is when it has a paucity of faction access and you're denied buying one. This results in extremely unfun games where you're at a point deficit without much to fight it.

The other biggest weaknesses D:I have: leaders are imbalanced. Ilban, depending on the expansion, can be busted OP. Intrigue draws are RNG and some are very overpowered (Corner the Market). Turn order has way too big an impact on the game.

I think ultimately the design choices of D:I would inevitably result in a pretty strong meta, and that in a skilled game, way too much is determined simply by the random setup in a way that reduces fun over time.

That said, is this game still good? Yes. You won't notice many of these issues unless you play with a dedicated group, and you can easily get 5-10 plays before noticing some of these issues. But is it a flawless masterpiece of a game? No.

A tense race-to-ten-points game.

The game is a combination of worker placement and deck building, where I feel both are decent, but not amazing.

Many compare this game with Arnak, and I feel they are totally different games so it wouldn't be a fair comparison.

Arnak is a strict resource conversion game, while Dune: Imperium feels more like a strategic battler (as it appears that most game wins result from well-timed combat wins).

The theme is okay, as I'm not a fan of the Dune universe.

Initial characters that you pick from have huge variation in power potential. Some will be lackluster while others have superb abilities.

The influence track race is implemented very well, and adds a level of complexity that adds to the tension.

My least favorite part is the randomness of intrigue cards and their huge variation in power levels.

My main concern with the game was game balance, in particular the intrigue/market cards and the heavy emphasis on combat for level-3 conflict cards, which results in combat spaces such as Heighliner being very powerful.

Buying from the "market row" also felt extremely luck based as the powers of these cards also had huge variations in power levels.

There is market row stagnation when playing with two players, so house ruling the market row to flush cards was necessary. I.E. 6 cards in the market instead of 5, one-time option to wipe the whole market per player, roll a die for the AI's reveal phase which wipes out the corresponding card in that row.

I felt the best part of Dune: Imperium was the tight race to 10 points. Every point felt worth it!

I feel there is a great opportunity for more games to implement tighter point races where each point feels highly rewarding.

I see why people like it. Not a hard learn at all, even though there are a few things you have to keep track of. First play was just “ok”, although it was at 2p. While, at first glance, it may seem like a game that could go on forever (if people keep knocking you down and you lose VPs), the opposite could happen as well if someone isn't interfered with . There's a lot of luck that happens in the first few rounds and you may not be able to really enjoy your well-built deck by the time that someone pulls off a win. For instance, there may be a consecutive turn where you can't put troops into conflict, or someone else just got to it before you and you lose by a hair. In that case, it may be that the top prize is TWO victory points. This happened in our game, and the game was over. A four point swing in short order. So, timing and luck are a big part of the game. Considering the speed at which the game *can* turn, I think that adding a mechanism where someone can shuffle their deck before running out of cards (and maybe even redraw?) would maybe mitigate that a little. I think this is one where it may take several plays to fully appreciate it, so you may want to borrow a copy before buying.

Leí las instruccciones, y mire a mi grupo de juego y les dije a esto ya sabéis jugar. En cada ronda habrá un combate. Tenéis dos trabajadores - podréis tener tres en el futuro - y en cada turno podéis mandar un trabajador jugando una carta a una localización (la carta te limita a cual puedes ir) y allí ejecutar lo que se puede hacer en ella. Las cartas que no has jugado te servirán para comprar más cartas y mejorar tu posición en el combate.

Nosotros: nosotros que jugamos el 80% de las veces a dos, este juego lo hemos probado a dos, te mete un bot que es la casa de Hagal, y no lo recomendamos. ¿puedes jugar? si y no es mal juego peero, pierde toda la tensión epicidad y mala leche del juego a 4. Es más, analizándolo en general yo como eurogamer veo que el juego no es perfecto (por ejemplo tiene algunos problemillas que resuelve mucho la ampliación el auge de IX), y no lo recomendaría alegremente. ¿y entonces porqué esta nota?

Ellos: Pese a lo que acabo de escribir, este juego es uno de los que encajan a la perfección en nuestro extraño grupo de mesa. Mucha interacción, profundo, diferentes estrategias para ganar, mucho de ir a degüello, y unos giros de guión con las cartas de intriga, el estar en la última ronda todos a un punto de la victoria, etc. que lo convierten en uno de nuestros juegos preferidos

A brilliant blend of deck building, worker placement and light combat. The card play integrates really well with the worker placement, and the low amount of victory points more often than not results in very tight and tense games. The multi-use cards work similarly to Clank! (same designer) but the card effects are improved and made much more interesting making the cards easily the highlight of the show. The only negative is the slight randomness of the intrigue cards that can sway the course of combat dramatically but it still seems to be at least somewhat negatable.

Dune: Imperium – A clever cocktail of deckbuilding, worker placement, and area control, all wrapped in the epic Dune universe. You’ll juggle gaining influence, managing resources, and waging battles while navigating the complex intrigues of the Great Houses. The mechanics mesh beautifully, offering a tactical playground where every choice counts and no strategy is safe from your rivals. It’s engaging, fast-paced, and constantly rewarding, with the spice of Dune’s setting adding just the right amount of desert heat. If you love multifaceted strategy with a side of political scheming and combat, this one’s a winner every time.
